docs.lead_paragraph: HYPNOSIS, once regarded as little more than a primitive ritual and parlor trick, beloved by mystics but scorned by medicine, has emerged in recent decades as a potent weapon in treating a host of medical problems.
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody article on hypnosis; discusses what it is, who should perform it and its value in treating pain and other medical and psychological problems (L)
docs.snippet: HYPNOSIS, once regarded as little more than a primitive ritual and parlor trick, beloved by mystics but scorned  by medicine, has emerged in recent decades as a potent weapon in treating a host of medical problems.

docs.lead_paragraph: HYPNOSIS, once regarded as little more than a primitive ritual and parlor trick, beloved by mystics but scorned by medicine, has emerged in recent decades as a potent weapon in treating a host of medical problems. As physicians, psychologists and other health professionals have come to better appreciate the effect of the mind on physical as well as emotional symptoms, hypnosis has found an increasingly wide application in the treatment of dental anxiety, phobias, headaches, warts, smoking, alcoholism, obesity, insomnia, nausea and bedwetting, and as an adjunct in the treatment of emotional problems.
